intro: Bupleurum commutatum subsp. glaucocarpum, commonly known as the glaucocarpum bellflower, is a member of the Apiaceae family. It is characterized by its slender, hairy stems and small, clustered flowers that range in color from white to pale blue. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils in mountainous regions. Its leaves are pinnately compound, with lance-shaped leaflets. It is often found in alpine or subalpine habitats, where it thrives in cool, moist conditions.
